PARAGRAPH.STRING: (Алматы; formerly known as Alma-Ata, also Vernyj, Vyernyi (Верный) in Imperial Russia) is the largest city in Kazakhstan, with a population of 1,185,900 (2004) (8% of the population of Kazakhstan) citizens.
The name "Almaty" means "appled" (the place with apples), the older version of

name, Alma-Ata, literally means "father-apple". In the surrounding region, unrivalled genetic diversity among the alma, the wild apples, implies that south-east Kazakhstan is where the domesticated apple is native.
A troop of Siberian Cossacks from Omsk founded
in 1854 at the foot of the Tian Shan mountain range, and renamed

one year later to Vernyj, a name that remained until 1921. In 1921, the name Alma-Ata ("father-apple") was created by the Bolsheviks. In a devastating earthquake in 1911, almost the only large building that remained standing was the Russian Orthodox cathedral. In the 1920s, after the completion of the Turkestan-Siberia Railway,
, as it was then known, became a major stopping point along the track. In 1929,
became the capital of the Kazakh SSR.
became the capital of the Republic of Kazakhstan, a designation
kept until 1998, when the capital was moved to Astana.

A short bus ride into the Tian Shan Mountains brings one to Medeo, a popular tourist destination, with several hotels and an Olympic-size skating rink.
